Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> The techniques progpow use are interesting and seem like legitimate ways to keep gpu/cpu relevant by utilizing hardware specific to themselves  and effectively making them asics. These concepts can be useful in finding new solutions and approaches to the inherent problems of maintaining balance in an ideally decentralized market. I don't want to get too hung up on any one fix as I'm sure they all have their trade-offs but I think it's good to consider all the angles. However it goes, I'm confident that because we have a clever and capable team working this out, we'll get the solution that suits us best.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> There are some real differences between what we're doing in VerusHash 2.0 and ProgPoW right now. ProgPoW ensures that low end commodity CPUs remain relevant for some time, they seem to feel indefinitely. We currently believe our approach solves some issues in a similar way, but others in a way that should be more resistant to bot nets. I'm looking forward to our discussions, and I can always learn. At the same time, I'm feeling pretty good about our approach for the long term. They are open source, and I've already looked through the source. Maybe she will illuminate some advantages of which I'm currently unaware.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <cryptonoobie> @Godballz thanks for sharing that post.  That was an extremely interesting and eye-opening read.  I think I'm a little smarter after reading it as well, if I understood everything correctly.  The referenced slides about blockchain attacks was excellent as well.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Greer> ProgPoW extends a memory hard algo, it is not an algo of its own. It is tuned for gpu not cpu.  The ethash implementation consumes ~10w per MH across most modern gpu‚Äôs. It is unlikely fpga‚Äôs or asics would do better than a 10% efficiency gain if anything at all. CPUs would not do well

Look at you Linux mining distro, in particular the tool that allows you to overclock your amd cards, it‚Äôll be named wolfamdctrl or the newer version renamed OhGodATool. The name should offer clues about any biases.

If still unconvinced, ProgPoW is open source code, read the code.

What happens when everyone adopts an f1 and the new f2 comes out? Same problem for miners, more money for the manufacturers. A more balanced solution is needed for long term sustainability. Pos, which we fortunately have, seems to be one and there are many talented minds working on a better pow now as well.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <Greer> @Takoy_Nahal up until the fmv exploit mentioned in the talk above ethash has been the most asic resistant which is why the current asics have such a small advantage over gpu‚Äôs.
The goal of ProgPoW isn‚Äôt to resist any kind of hardware, instead, get consistent hash per watt across all hardware types so that one does not have an advantage over another because as soon as one has an advantage all you did was push difficulty up and centralized your hash. This is explained by Kristys Medium post and misunderstood by so many, otherwise smart, people.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Greer> The current implementation of ProgPoW extends ethash, it could be applied to other memory hard algorithms such as equihash or possibly mtp

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Takoy_Nahal> @Greer Since Asic and FPGA inevitably come to every GPU algorithm, the Progpow solution looks the most reasonable. The coexistence of all types of mining tools where no one has an advantage sounds great

If they can do that there is more money in selling gpu‚Äôs.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <Greer> Save on electric bills?  Consider a new miner only burns 1 watt per MH instead of 10 watts per MH.  Someone running a farm can now afford to run 10x more miners, the difficulty goes up and everyone buys more hardware.  Same amount of energy is now being burned, same amount of reward per watt spent (because of difficulty) just more hardware to burn it.
https://medium.com/@OhGodAGirl/the-problem-with-proof-of-work-da9f0512dad9

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <Greer> The only metric that matters in PoW is watts burned per hash. 
People will always try to game that to be one of few gaining more of a share of the reward while burning less electricity, if successful they devalue all other miners rewards, centralize the hash and devalue the project.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Gloryman> Hi @miketout . This is a really interesting idea and it would take a lot of consideration. Firstly, I think it would limit the coin income on people using cpus and gpus because it would increase the total hash rate but reduce the hash ratio for cpus and gpus. Secondly, I think it would therefore make it harder to encourage new miners and new members to the community. Thirdly, buying an FPGA for 1 coin is a big and risky investment in my opinion. If verus coin falls then we would have wasted $500. Fourthly, buying verus FPGAs doesn't guarantee that other FPGA makers can make faster FPGAs and therefore make our FPGA useless. If you could address these issues I would be very grateful. I'm quite undecided about this issue

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Gloryman> Hey  @miketout I have some ideas on this. Firstly, I think there are better ways to attract new people, like raindrops and games. I have got so many alt coins of coins I don't even know they are for. And, lots of people have fun chatting on these forums. It's also a great way for us to get other people involved from other forums because everyone want free coins and this would only cost the foundation a few dollars a day. Secondly, I think fpgas being based on multiples of cpu miners will really limit the impact of fpgas on the hash rates because it will chase off the super heavy ROI chasers. Also, people in the community will likely not be coin dumping and therefore driving the coin down. A more stable coin is more attractive and might mean that cpu miners make more money because they Will get less of a ratio of the hash but a coin that has a higher dollar value (assuming u can stop the other fpgas). Thirdly, another way to reduce the risk of fpgas limiting newbies is if the fpgas had other coins that could be mined for a similar level of profit. Forthly, another great way to encourage new people is to host fpgas and buy part of that fpga, like sell 20% for $100. Fithly, another way to help new people is to donate hash to small old cpu miners and gpu miners if they are mining at 100 mhs on and old cpu, you could use part of the fpga farm to give them 200mhs.  Sixthly, lol, I think the biggest problem is not a well devised fpga implementation. The biggest problem is protecting the network from super big and aggressive fpga miners, because they damage the coins stability as well as the community miners. If u can sell fpgas and limit the big fpgas, you got us self a winner. Just my thoughts.
